An even better light source would probably be an arc-lamp. They are made of two sharp carbon rods with the points real close together. Light is produces by arcing electricity between the points. Very cool video. My only nit would be when he talks about his parabolic mirror being a subset of a larger sphere. Parabolas are not subsets of circles. A circle (or sphere) is the set of points equidistant from a single point. A parabola (or paraboloid) is the set of points that are individually equidistant from a single point and a line (or plane). These are different things entirely. He should not be equivalencing the two.

The knife edge is strictly not necessary. I replicated your setup with a smaller mirror and found that to be so.

Reasons - the camera is looking into a mirror with an object under investigation right in front of it. So the camera will see the object itself, and its reflection in the mirror slightly displaced and slightly enlarged. The object under observation happen to be air - but the mirror principle holds nevertheless. What that means is that the irregularity in reflective index will cause a slightly different image in the mirror, and the camera is seeing both in slight displacement with each other. The overlapping of the two images will give a very strong Schlieren effect without the need for the knife edge, good enough to show random air flow and clapping of hands.

There's a bunch of cool things you could do with a model of an airplane wing (a basic asymmetrical airfoil made out of cardboard or styrofoam or something) and a fan with a laminar flow nozzle (these also seem to be relatively simple to build out of stuff like drinking straws):

* Increase the wing's angle of attack until you get flow separation (the wing stalls) and film the turbulence on top of the wing

* Film the wingtip vortex with and without a winglet at the tip of the wing to see how winglets make airplanes more efficient

* Tape a small rectangular piece of cardboard to the top of the wing, prop it up at various angles between 0 and 90 degrees to act as a spoiler and film the vortex it produces

* Repeat the previous test but with the cardboard piece taped to the trailing edge of the wing and angled downwards to act as a flap

About 15 years ago I worked on a project to get Schlieren interferometry to work in 2 dimensions rather than the standard single dimension that is used in this setup.

We used it to restore distorted images captured at high mach velocities.

Instead of a knife to cut the light, we used a filter with 4 quadrants.

1 quadrant was white or magenta (lets through blue and red), another quadrant was red (cuts blue) another was blue (cuts red) and another was black or green (cuts blue and red).

This way you have 1 knife cutting the blue light, and another knife cutting the red light and you can get a 2 dimensional image that can later be processed by a computer.

Another way to make Schlieren work is with a wheel. We had one wheel with magenta and red alternating, and another wheel with magenta and blue alternating and when you overlap the wheel so that the lines make 90 deg angles you get the same effect, however you can keep turning the wheel to adjust the effects.

A Schlieren Optic can also be used to image diffraction.  I have done this with my optics class and it works well.  The best way to see this is to turn all lights off, other than the point source.  Diffraction at the edges of objects is then clearly visible.  I have shown my students the diffraction around my arm hair, for example.  I like the fact that the set up can be used to see both diffraction and refraction.  A video on diffraction would raise some interesting physics.

With just a knife edge you can only really visualize density gradients in one direction projected onto the image. In your setup, your knife edge is horizontal, so it will occult rays that are deflected down due to changes in density/refractive index, corresponding to density gradients aligned in the verticle direction. But with color schleiren you can create colored slide filters that can highlight multiple gradient orientations. And the pictures look cool, due to the bright, fancy colors. You could try, as a first hack, printing designs onto transparencies.

You can see a similar effect if you have a Newtonian reflecting telescope and you find a bright star. Defocus the star so you see a large disk, usually with a black spot in the middle from the secondary mirror. It is quite easy to see air currents created by your own body heat if you place you hand at the open end of the tube while looking in the eyepiece. I first noticed it when I had a small heater attached to the secondary mirror to prevent dew and accidentally turned it up too high and the air currents coming off it were amazing!!

I would suggest investigating this effect bellow and above visible electromagnetic spectrum (different type of sensor).

1. I assume, that utilizing higher frequencies would be more sensitive due to higher level of refraction/dispersion for the same physical circumstances such as temperature, concentration of the "fluid" in question, etc.

2. Also, it would be interesting to investigate, if energy of the transmitted electromagnetic wave is dependent of angle of incidence, as a consequence of the density and velocity of the electromagnetic wave in the particular "fluid", which, by analogy with reflection seismic methods, such as AVA/AVO (Amplitude versus Angle&Offset of incidence), that is widely used in seismic characterization of the physical properties of the rocks with different saturation of the hydrocarbons, would give a hint what type of "unknown" fluid we are dealing with.

3. Application in medicine/radiology: Will ''scanning'' with wider frequency range of source (i.e. linearly modulated frequency sweep) would reveal specific character of the tissue in question, that could be quantified, improving diagnostic procedure.

4. Does different "fluids" perform polarization and, if so, could this effect could be utilized as a tool for characterization of the emanated material in the known environment (in this case air or, maybe, in the vacuum, for more precise quantification), by detecting the same image with 2 sensor with 90 degrees polarized filters, where image (function in time) for each particular pixel, that records this process as afunction in time, could be treated as Analytical signal [GEOPHYSICS. VOL. 44. NO. 6 (JUNE 1979); Complex seismic trace analysis - M. T. Taner*, F. Koehler*, and R. E. Sheriff*], where instantaneous attributes of the recorded transmitted electromagnetic energy, could be derived, such as phase, frequency, energy, polarity, and many others.

5. Could such "devices", with appropriate real time processing, be utilized for permanent scanning of the atmosphere, in order to define amount and types of air pollutant around the Earth globe, of any kind - i.e., distinguishing burned airplane fuel from chem trails, etc., since we have cosmic radiation of the wide frequency range as a source.

Once again, thank you for the brilliant demonstration!

8. Get Destin to shoot something! You'd get big pressure & temperature effects.
9. An air vortex cannon.
10. Write your channel name in Schlieren shadow...

It's possible to create this effect to some extend just by putting some distance between a flame and light source.  If you use a  lamp with a shroud and ordinary tungsten 100 watt  light bulb (what I used) and direct the light toward a white wall 4 or 5 meters away holding a small lit hand-held butane torch about midway between lamp and wall (what seemed to work best overall), this will bring out/amplify the roiling heated air currents. You can twist and turn or invert the torch in the light to vary  the flow visualization.

Even with your explanation and online research I still don't understand how this works. I understand how light beams are refracted and selected, but I don't understand why the recorded image looks like what it looks like. Why does the camera still see the whole mirror when you place the razor blade right in front of it, cutting off half the LED light in the process? Why don't you see only half of the mirror? What influence does the camera's distance to the setup have?

Maybe you could show some experiments with small changes of the setup, e.g. a different orientation of the blade, another type of cutoff (like an iris diaphragm or something like a needle cutting the middle part of the focussed LED light), different camera distances etc. A diagram showing light paths would also be helpful (if it includes the paths in the camera, I have seen enough pictures that are only about what happens at the focal point of the LED light, which I had no problem understanding in the first place).

Instead of blocking half of the photons with a razor blade, could you refract them with a dispersive prism? By blocking half of the light you are essentially asking a binary question: "was the photon refracted enough either to be blocked or to avoid being blocked?" Oversimplifying it a bit for ease of understanding, your resulting image is like a monochrome image that varies only in luminosity. Using a prism you instead are asking a question with potentially infinite answers: "by how much was each photon refracted?" Oversimplifying again, the prism could give you a color image that dynamically varies in luminosity, hue, and saturation.

In school I remember doing the electrolysis of water and storing oxygen and hydrogen in separate test tubes — the latter being upside down. An activity that we worked on building an inquiry component to is how salinity effects the density of water, and how that affects ocean currents. Specifically what I would love to see/show my students is what it looks like to have cold salt water, then warm salt water, then cold fresh water, then warm fresh water. Great video, this is a topic I really enjoy. For anyone interested in trying it out, a similar setup is possible without a camera, and it allows real-time projection (it can be used for a classroom demo in fact). Here's a (low quality :-) video that shows an example of what I mean: https://vimeo.com/63931717

I've also managed to make it work with a makeup mirror in a hotel bathroom. It turns out the LED next to a macbook webcam is a great source for the light you need. A laptop and a mirror is the most minimal setup I've gotten to work. Try it!

The single razor blade edge lets you see gradients in one direction, but I'd be interested to see gradients in two. I don't know if the result would look too busy, but the colourizing would capture direction which you can't otherwise see.

If the colourizing doesn't look too busy, you might take it further with three LEDs, red green and blue, and as many edges angled 60 degrees from each other.

I have often thought I could see temp gradients at just the right angle through peripheral vision...I wonder if the anatomy of how our eyes sit in our heads could provide similar visual effects with just the right conditions? I make tea everyday in a cast iron teapot on an induction cooker which is quite fast, but the teapot has no whistle so I just watch for the steam to billow to know the water is hot enough for brewing. Every so often I will catch a "plume" out of the corner of my eye, but when I look at the teapot directly, there's no actual steam billowing yet, but when I hold my hand over the mouth of the teapot, I feel a plume of heat, and then a few seconds later, the steam typically starts. I've often wondered if I was just getting the timing of my induction cooker, but now after seeing this video, I wonder if I was stumbling onto something? food for thought ;)

p.s. i have some very thick anti-reflective coated glasses that I always wear, but the plume is only visible at the very edge of the peripheral field for me, outside of the line of sight of the lenses...so its very blurry, but I have decent movement detection and I have been told my peripheral vision field is wider than average...side note, I also enjoy cannabis regularly...lots of factors to consider lol.

final edit: can you put a cell phone receiving/sending signals in front of that camera? I also have thought I caught something in peripherals right before receiving a call/text in the past :)

I;ve been thinking about this for a month or so, since regular visual light can be refracted by gases and heat differences.

Beats in sound created when two slightly distinct frequencies overlap, creating constructive and destructive interference.

This setup is also the basis for the Foucault test, which is used to measure the parabolic curve of the mirror: move the razor blade slightly forward and back such that it cuts into part of the light cone reflected by the mirror and you can cause specific areas on the mirror's surface to go dark. By measuring the distance of the razor blade from the focus and the area on the mirror that it darkens at a given spot and you can measure how close the surface is to a true parabola.

Fun fact: the Hubble Telescope's mirror was shown to be defective by a Foucault test, but Perkin Elmer ignored the results because they preferred the more complicated null test, the equipment for which they had incorrectly assembled. Kodak created the Hubble's back up mirror and figured it using the Foucault test, and this mirror was perfect.

Ooh! You should totally make a sonic black hole and view it in schlieren!

"A sonic black hole, sometimes called a dumb hole, is a phenomenon in which phonons (sound perturbations) are unable to escape from a fluid that is flowing more quickly than the local speed of sound. They are called sonic, or acoustic, black holes because these trapped phonons are analogous to light in astrophysical (gravitational) black holes. Physicists are interested in them because they have many properties similar to astrophysical black holes and, in particular, emit a phononic version of Hawking radiation.[1][2] The border of a sonic black hole, at which the flow speed changes from being greater than the speed of sound to less than the speed of sound, is called the event horizon. At this point the frequency of phonons approaches zero."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonic_black_hole

Very cool video.  However, a "parabolic mirror" can't form part of a "spherical shell".  A parabolic mirror reflects light originating at its focal point as parallel rays.  A spherical mirror reflects light originating at its center back to its center.

Good video, i have just a small gripe with it.
Schlieren photography doesn't visualize the temperature gradients and pressure differences, technically speaking. The refractive index is dependent on the density gradient (which in turn influences temperature and pressure and vice versa ofc). Same goes for Mach-Zehnder interferometers, only with the second derivate of density in space.

As an ex-aerodynamicist, you bring back many happy memories of using Schlieren systems to investigate transonic flows over a whole bunch of different shapes. You might like to try to produce "colour Schlieren", where you replace the razor blade with a discrete colour filter - we used to use different coloured bits of transparent gel used in theatre lighting. The only problem is to get the filter small enough to produce the desired colour changes. But it's great fun trying! Good luck.
